intro: Sinapis virgata, commonly known as the slender mustard, is an annual herbaceous plant native to temperate regions of Europe and Asia. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes many other mustard species. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with slender stems and alternate leaves that are lance-shaped and hairy. Its small, yellow flowers are arranged in racemes and bloom in the spring, followed by the production of slender, cylindrical pods containing several seeds. Sinapis virgata is often found in disturbed soils and is sometimes considered a weed in agricultural settings.
